Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Award: Establishing A Wild Resource Isotopic Baseline For Behavioral Reconstruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the direction of Dr. Joan Coltrain Mr. Michael Lewis will collect data for his doctoral dissertation. These consist of isotope values derived from present day plants located on the Cedar Mesa in southeast Utah. With this information it will be possible to gain insight into the diet of prehistoric farmers on the Colorado Plateau. The goal of the research is to use isotopic data derived from human skeletal material to reconstruct individuals' diets and then gain insight into group social organization. This project translates sex-based differences in human bone chemistry into distinct dietary differences, clarifying the economic roles of men and women in prehistoric society. While the data to be collected will be used to reconstruct the past, the information will also have relevance for understanding water, soil and plant interactions in the desert west, and will contribute to developing strategies for responsibly balancing preservation, recreation and economic development on the Colorado Plateau.

This project has four components. First, the investigators will analyze modern flora collected on Cedar Mesa, southeast Utah in 2014. Sampling locations will be selected to determine the extent to which environmental variation can influence isotope ratios within a single species. Second, bone collagen from faunal specimens from archaeological sites on Cedar Mesa will be obtained, extracted and analyzed. This will permit researchers to estimate the isotopic values of lean muscle consumed by prehistoric hunters. Third, pit-roasting of banana yucca "hearts", an important component of Cedar Mesa prehistoric diet, will be simulated under controlled conditions, permitting the isotopic comparison of the edible portion of the heart with the composition of yucca fibers which are often recovered archaeologically. Finally, the above plant and animal will then combined with published data on human burials from the Cedar Mesa area to reconstruct diet. This will permit researchers to determine the relative contributions of plant and animal foods in a cross gender comparison. Results will be published to the scientific community and presented to the public through local educational outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Doctoral Dissertation Research Award: Establishing a Wild Resource Isotopic Baseline for Basketmaker II Diet on Cedar Mesa.

The American Southwest has one of the best preserved and documented prehistoric archaeological records in the world—spanning terminal Pleistocene big game hunting to socially stratified cultural complexes like the Hohokam, Hopi and other Puebloan peoples. These cultures lived in above ground room blocks, built large food storage structures, exhibited public architecture like kivas and engaged in long distance trade. This archaeological record is matched by high resolution paleo-climatic data making the American Southwest uniquely suited to address one of the central issues in prehistory: when and why did people begin to farm, how important were domesticated foods in their diets and what were the social implications of reliance on domesticates?

On the Colorado Plateau, several recent studies have focused on the social and technological changes associated with the adoption of pottery, village life and recognizable Puebloan life-ways. Unfortunately, while the ceramic periods, post–AD 500, are thoroughly studied, the prior a-ceramic period—Basketmaker II (BM II)—is less well understood. The lower population density and greater mobility of BM II populations produced fewer and less visible sites even though they are thought to be the first farmers in the Four Corners region of the American Southwest. Investigators offer substantially different reconstructions of BM II diets. In particular, conclusions reached by current stable isotope diet models differ from results obtained using more conventional archeological approaches such as the examination of settlement patterns, animal bone assemblages and plant materials found at BM II sites. 

Carbon and nitrogen stable isotope studies used to reconstruct past diets document the molecular characteristics of bone protein, which vary with intake of animal protein and maize, first grown in the Four Corners region by BM II people. Previous research with a large collection of burials from well-known archaeological sites on Cedar Mesa and in Grand Gulch, UT, reported that BM II people appeared surprisingly heavily reliant on maize. Maize comprised 65-70% of their caloric intake. This study also found that adult males ate more animal protein from large prey like mule deer and bighorn sheep than adult females or adolescents. These results indicated heavy reliance on maize, beginning very early, by 100 BC or slightly before, indicating that farmers moved into the region from southern Arizona, and suggested that adult males engaged in feasting associated with large animal kills, which females participated in less often.  Social and gender based distinctions of this type are of great interest to archaeologists and often hard to document.

The project titled above was designed to reexamine BM II diets and the reported difference between male and female diets in particular. Animals from archaeological sites and modern plants were collected from Cedar Mesa and Grand Gulch to provide a local isotopic reconstruction of the foods these BM II groups were eating. The food data used previously to reconstruct BM II diets came from areas in Utah but not immediately adjacent to the cave sites where burials were found. Soil chemistry and precipitation can affect the carbon and nitrogen chemistry of foods, which is passed up the food chain leaving a diagnostic signature in our bones. Since BM II groups were the first farmers in the Four Corner Region, did maize truly comprise more than 65% of their diet? Were males feasting more often and eating more meat? Did a gender hierarchy exist even though BM II people lived in pithouses, stored maize in small, rock shelter caches and exhibited few if any signs of social stratification? Local food data were needed to address these questions, all of which inform our understanding of how farming affects mobility, social structure and gender roles.

Local food resources did exhibit slightly altered average carbon and nitrogen values but these values varied widely. The characteristics of Cedar Mesa and Grand Gulch diets that were reported previously remain unchanged. Some important methodological advances were made but the outcome of this study does not significantly alter the results of previous work. We can now report with greater confidence that maize intake was very high and adult males did consume more meat from large animals than females. With pre- industrial farming comes a codification of gender roles that typically exceeds that of forager populations. Adult males feast to maintain coalitional bonds with other males, enhancing status and influence. Adult females snare small animals like rabbits but appear to have less access to high prestige foods like large animal kills. Social stratification appears to be a pervasive characteristic associated with even early reliance on domesticates in the Four Corners region of the American Southwest.
